_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The ALEUS operation at 3322 Road N NE utilizes the following accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source:
-	Systems are designed by engineers
-	Standard operating procedures to ensure the facility is operated as designed
-	Management of change to ensure the covered process is not altered without a safety review
-	Operator training to ensure correct operating procedure (SOP)
-	Operator training to ensure emergency response including shutting down systems to limit the impact of potential release
-	Enforcement of area electrical classification and conforming equipment
-	Safety training for all personnel on site

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:
The substance which triggers 40 CFR 68 compliance is hydrogen, stored in both liquid and gas form.  The primary function of the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) facility at 3322 Road N NE is to supply bulk gasses to our customer via pipeline on a 24 hour, 365-day basis. Bulk gasses other than hydrogen are inert and non-regulated by this program (nitrogen, argon). 

The facility manufactures hydrogen by process of catalytic reformation.  During the process of manufacturing hydrogen, methane is combined with steam at high temperatures in a two-phase reaction to generate hydrogen and water. Hydrogen is stored in liquid form in stationary bulk tanks and transported in gaseous form via pipeline to the on-site customer.

The ALEUS stationary source located at 3322 Road N NE, includes two 2,673 cubic foot (20,000 US gallon) vacuum-insulated cryogenic, horizontal) tanks of liquefied hydrogen, two 4,000 cubic foot (30,000 US gallon (horizontal) tanks of hydrogen gas, and small amounts of hydrogen within the process vessels and piping.

The chemical specific accidental release and accident prevention steps are those used to mitigate risk from flammable gases. Employees are consulted and trained on the process using standard operating procedures. The equipment was des

igned by engineers. Documentation pertaining to the design of the process and recommended maintenance / integrity inspections are followed.

Process hazard analysis by HAZOP has been used to identify potential concerns and ensure mitigation to low levels of risk per ALEUS policy.

When contractors are used on the site, rigorous selection and training specific to the site is performed to ensure potential hazards of contractors are mitigated.

A hot work program in conjunction with a Safe Work Permit system is used to lower risk from hot work.  A Management of Change process is used for any alterations to the system.

An incident investigation process applied at multiple facilities in different geographic areas facilitates the timely review of all similar systems operated by Air Liquide ensuring identified risks are mitigated.

All employees are trained on the sites emergency action plan, which includes the assistance of the local fire department and the LEPC.

Audits of the system are conducted periodically and a pre-startup review occurs prior to startup after any significant change.

This facility complies with the EPA accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The covered bulk tanks were designed / installed and is maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and Washington state law.

In addition, the Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP (ALEUS) facility at 3322 Road N NE utilizes safety equipment such as:
-	Gauges and internal piping to ensure the bulk tanks are operated at or below maximum allowable working pressure capacity
-	Overpressure relief valves for pressure vessels per ASME code
-	Fail-closed emergency shut-off valves
-	Relief valves on compressor piping
-	Process alarms and interlocks in the downstream processes, sensitive to: flows, steam to carbon ratios, pressures, temperatures, and levels
-	Manual emergency shutdown system
-	Nearby water cannons (commonly called monitors)
-	Manual isolation valv

es to safeguard the system, ensure a safe range of operation and actively mitigate events that fall outside of those parameters.

The ALEUS facility at 3322 Road N NE utilizes an Emergency Action Plan, Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs), and Emergency Action Plan Training to ensure personnel are trained to identify and respond to accident and emergency situations. Actual response to an emergency would be by the  City of Moses Lake Fire Department. 

The ALEUS plant at 3322 Road N NE would respond to accidental releases from the covered process by
-	Notification of all persons on site
-	Notification of contiguous industrial site by telephone
-	Notification of local fire department by telephone
-	Stopping equipment and isolating any equipment which may leak flammable gases
-	Isolation of bulk tank via remote emergency stop
-	Evacuation of the area
-	Coordination with the local fire department and LEPC.
